column4: i was trying to change my username via instructions found on this website http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?p=4968235 but now I am receiving a User's $HOME/.dmrc file is being ignored error. I have no other user names and can not get into my system. Any help would be appreciated.
just delete the file... its just a 1 line file that has the last login/desktop setting..
it will get remade next time you login

- it won't let me log in, that error message is followed by a "Your session only lasted less than 10 seconds. Iff you have not logged out yourself, this could mean that there is some installation problem or that you may be out of diskspace. Try loggin in with one of the failsafe sessions to see if you can fix this problem."
- it then goes back to the login screen
if that file is the problem. login at the alt-ctrl-f1 consoles and  delete it.
then alt-ctrl-f7 to  get back to the login screen.. its possible you got some other permissions issues going on.
- how do i change permissions to a folder in shell so that I have full permission over it
you wish to change the usres home directory from /home/USERNAME to what exactly?
- i changed my username but apparently my new username is linked to my old username's home folder. I want the new homefolder to be the same as the new username
how did you change your username?  and why.
sudo mkdir /home/newusername  and 'sudo chown username.username /home/username 'it to be owned by the new user  for starters i guess..
i hope you properly changed the commands to be the new/old users names.. and  not 's_old_newg' like the examples show
look in /home/ the users directory does exist? thats one thing to check.
if it exists thats step 1 done.. Now to double check  /etc/passwd and /etc/group and /etc/shadow is the next thing.
so there is no /home/CURRENTUSERNAME ?
but you have sort of 'half way' switched to the new username?  you are logged in as the new username?
so make a /home/newusername dir and make it owned by that user perhaps? if im understanding you right.
so all the /etc/ Files check out..  just no /home/NewUserName directory?

I would just make the new users home dir by hand (with sudo mkdir, and sudo chown whatever) and then copy all the old files from the old users dir over.. and fix their permissions.. or do like Flannel  says.
i always just add a new user. :) then move stuff over...
Im betting you did one of those commands wrong in the url you gave.
the usermod -d /home/new  -m old    command SHOULD of made the new home dir..
